x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement: War, conflict, and displacement cause people to lose identity documents, health records, and education credentials. Without verified identity, displaced persons struggle to access aid, healthcare, cash assistance, education, and legal protection. Aid duplication, fraud, and slow service delivery increase suffering and waste resources.

How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

  1. App Engine Studio : build the digital identity registry, credential records, and consent workflows.
  2. IntegrationHub : connect to biometric providers, UNHCR/ID systems, national registries, and verification APIs.
  3. Integrated Risk Management (IRM) : enforce data protection policies, access controls, and audit trails.
  4. Customer Service Management (CSM) : support desk for identity recovery, appeals, and verification requests.
  5. Flow Designer : automate onboarding, verification flows, and cross-agency approvals.
  6. Performance Analytics : dashboards for coverage, verification latency, and fraud indicators.
  7. Mobile App / Offline Framework :enable field workers to register and verify IDs in low-connectivity areas.
  8.  

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

  • Biometric SDKs or QR/PKI infrastructure for secure identifiers.

  • Integration with UNHCR, national civil registries, or trusted third-party ID providers.

  • Secure cloud storage and key management for encrypted personal data.

  • SMS/email gateways for notifications and recovery; offline sync (MQTT or similar) for field use.

  • Compliance with local/regional data protection laws (GDPR-like frameworks).

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

  • Legal and ethical concerns around biometrics and consent in fragile settings.

  • Interoperability with a wide range of legacy registries and standards.

  • Ensuring robust privacy, encryption, and access governance to prevent misuse.

  • Building trust with communities wary of digital IDs or surveillance.

  • Operationalizing recoverability when devices are lost or compromised.
